raw_text:
Joke e-mail virus tricks users
 
 A virus that disguises itself as a joke is spreading rapidly across the net.
 
 Anti-virus firms are issuing high-level warnings about the new version of the Bagle e-mail program that seems to be catching a lot of people out. The Windows virus grabs e-mail addresses from Microsoft Outlook and uses its own mail sending software to spread itself to new victims. When it infects a machine, the Bagle variant turns off security measures that usually protect PCs.
 
 The new variant is called Bagle.AT, Bagle.BB and Bagle.AU and the attachment bearing the virus code is labelled as either "joke" or "price".
 
 The body of the virus usually contains nothing but a smiley or emoticon. The virus can strike computers running Windows 95, 98, ME, NT, 2000 and XP. Users will be infected if they open the attachment that travels with the e-mail. As well as plundering Microsoft Outlook for e-mail addresses to send itself to, Bagle.AT also tries to turn off the firewall and security centre services on Windows XP machines. BBC News Online has received five warnings about the virus from security companies. Finnish company F-Secure gave the virus its second highest threat level. "We've had several reports all over the world," said Mikko Hypponen, director of anti-virus research for F-Secure. Security firm Network Box said that it stopped more than 30,000 copies an hour of the virus as the outbreak reached a peak. Black Spider said it had stopped more than 1 million copies of Bagle.AT since the outbreak began at 0630 BST (0530 GMT). Anti-virus firms urged users to be wary of unexpected e-mail messages bearing attachments and to update their software to ensure they are protected against the latest threats.
llama3.2:1b: A virus called Bagle is spreading across the net, disguising itself as a joke email attachment that infects Microsoft Outlook by stealing addresses and using its own mail sending software to spread to new victims.
The virus turns off security measures on Windows machines, particularly those running XP.
It contains no malicious code but can still cause problems for users.
llama3.2:3b: A joke email virus called Bagle is spreading rapidly across the net, infecting computers running Windows 95-XP by grabbing Outlook email addresses and disabling security measures.
The virus can be identified by an attachment labeled "joke" or "price", with a smiley face in the body.
Anti-virus firms have issued warnings, with some stopping over 30,000 copies per hour of the virus, and are urging users to update their software and be cautious of unexpected e-mail messages.
gemma2:2b: A new version of the Bagle email virus is spreading rapidly, disguised as a joke.
It uses Microsoft Outlook to access email addresses, disables security measures on Windows machines, and targets users who open infected attachments.
This variant (Bagle.AT, Bagle.BB, and Bagle.AU) often utilizes a smiley face as part of its payload.
The virus has a high threat level and is being actively stopped by anti-virus firms.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A new virus disguised as a joke is spreading rapidly across the net, infecting over 1 million copies in just one day at 0530 GMT (7 August) in the UK.
The attack uses Microsoft Outlook and an attachment that bears the "joke" or "price" code.
Anti-virus firms have issued high-level warnings about the new version of Bagle e-mail program, which seems to be catching a lot of people out.
They advise users to be wary of unexpected e-mail messages bearing attachments and to update their software to ensure they are protected against the latest threats.
qwen2.5:1.5b: A new version of Bagle, a computer virus disguised as jokes, is spreading rapidly via email.
It targets Windows 95, 98, ME, NT, 2000, and XP systems, using Microsoft Outlook for address lists and shutting down security features on Windows XP machines.
The virus's attachments often contain only smiley or emoticon messages that can infect users who open them.
It has caused warnings from security firms like F-Secure, Network Box, and Black Spider.
qwen2.5:3b: A rapidly spreading virus, disguised as a joke, is infecting computers through Microsoft Outlook.
Known as Bagle variants (AT, BB, AU), it uses victims' emails to spread itself.
The malware turns off security measures on Windows machines and disables firewall services in XP.
It appears via attachments labeled "joke" or "price".
High-level warnings have been issued by anti-virus firms like F-Secure and Network Box.
Security companies recommend users be cautious of unexpected e-mails with attachments, update software to protect against threats.
opencoder:1.5b: The virus tricking users into opening emails containing links to download a bait, often known as Joke Email Virus.
The new variant, Bagle.AT, is designed to infect Outlook computers running Windows XP.
smollm:1.7b: The joke email virus tricks users by disguising itself as a legitimate e-mail attachment, spreading rapidly across the net.
It uses its own mail sending software to infect new victims and shuts down security measures that usually protect PCs.
The Bagle variant is called Bagle.AT, Bagle.BB and Bagle.AU and the attachment bearing the virus code is labelled as either "joke" or "price".
The body of the virus usually contains nothing but a smiley or emoticon.
It tries to turn off security measures that usually protect PCs by sending itself an e-mail with the attachment.
As well as plundering Microsoft Outlook for e-mail addresses to send itself to, Bagle.AT also tries to turn off the firewall and security centre services on Windows XP machines.
BBC News Online has received five warnings about the virus from security companies.
Finnish company F-Secure gave the virus its second highest threat level.
"We've had several reports all over the world," said Mikko Hypponen, director of anti-virus research for F-Secure.
Security firm Network Box said that it stopped more than 30,000 copies an hour of the virus as the outbreak reached a peak.
Black Spider said it had stopped more than 1 million copies of Bagle.AT since the outbreak began at 0630 BST (0530 GMT).
Anti-virus firms urged users to be wary of unexpected e-mail messages bearing attachments and to update their software to ensure they are protected against the latest threats.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Joke email virus tricks users by pretending to send e-mails with funny attachments, known as "jokes" or "price."
Anti-virus firms warn about a new variant called Bagle,AT and similar versions, targeting computers running specific Windows versions.
The virus uses emoticons as payload and turns off security on XP machines for extra trickery.
tinyllama:1.1b:
Premisa: una virus joke infecta a las máquinas con Windows 95, 98, ME, NT, 2000 y XP

Cuál es el código del nuevo virus joke, llamado Bagle.AT, Bagle.BB y Bagle.AU?
El cuerpo del virus contiene nada más que un disgusto o un emoción.
El virus infecta las máquinas con Windows 95, 98, ME, NT, 2000 y XP y trata de recaudar el nombre de Outlook para enviarse a ellas mismo.

Además de plandear la configuración firewall y servicio de seguridad en Microsoft Outlook para las máquinas con Windows XP, también trata de apagar los servicios de seguridad de Security Center y Firewall de Windows 2000 y Xeon.
Los anti-virus de Finlandia F-Secure, Network Box y Black Spider han informado que se ha prohibido más de 30 milhões de copias del virus anual durante la noche del 6 al 7 de enero.
El virus ha estado atingiendo la máquina desde las 06:30 (BST) a la hora actual (EST).

Las empresas anti-virus, como Network Box y Black Spider, han pedido a sus usuarios que vigían ante los e-mails no deseados con atributos de correo electrónico e invierten su software antivirus para protegerse contra las últimas amenazas.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Bagle e-mail virus spreads rapidly across the internet, using its own mail sending software to infect computers running Microsoft Outlook, thereby bypassing common security measures.
The new variant of Bagle is called Bagle.AT and is labeled as either "joke" or "price."
It appears that users will receive email attachments with the virus code "AT," which stands for joke.
The virus infects computers running Windows 95, 98, ME, NT, 2000, and XP.
phi:2.7b: A virus that pretends to be a joke is spreading quickly online, infecting Windows XP computers with an attachment called "joke" or "price".
The virus uses Microsoft Outlook's address book to send itself to new victims, and it also tries to disable security features on some machines.
It has caused concern among anti-virus companies, who have issued warnings to users about the new variant of the Bagle e-mail program.
orca-mini:3b: A new virus called Bagle.AT is spreading rapidly across the net, posing a threat to computers running Windows 95, 98, ME, NT, 2000, and XP.
The virus can infect machines if they open the attachment that travels with the e-mail.
It tries to turn off firewall and security center services on Windows XP machines.
F-Secure gave the virus its second highest threat level, while other security firms also issued high warnings.
The virus has stopped more than 30,000 copies an hour of itself, and more than 1 million copies of Bagle.AT since the outbreak began at 0630 BST (0530 GMT).
Anti-virus firms urged users to be wary of unexpected e-mail messages bearing attachments and to update their software to ensure they are protected against the latest threats.
hermes3:3b: Bagle virus (Bagle.AU, AT, BB), joke-email virus spreading rapidly, disguises as attachment "joke" or "price".
Infected computers get security measures turned off, allowing the virus to spread and plunder Outlook for e-mail addresses.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: A new variant of the Bagle email virus, called Bagle.AT, Bagle.BB and Bagle.AU, is disguising itself as a joke and spreading rapidly across the internet.
Anti-virus firms warn users about this new version, which turns off security measures once it infects a machine.
The virus plunders Microsoft Outlook for e-mail addresses and tries to turn off firewall and security center services on Windows XP machines.
Users are advised to be cautious of unexpected email attachments and update their anti-virus software to protect against the latest threats.
stablelm2:1.6b: A virus disguised as a joke is spreading rapidly on the internet, targeting Microsoft Outlook email accounts with its Bagle e-mail program.
The Windows virus tricks machines into sharing email addresses and uses its own mail sending software to spread itself.
The new Bagle variant can infect Windows 7, ME, NT, XP, and Windows Vista systems.
Infected users will open attachments labeled as "joke" or "price," which contains the virus code.
The body of the virus is usually a smiley emoticon with no malicious content.
Security companies have warned users to be cautious of unexpected e-mail messages containing attachment files and update their software for protection against the new threats.
granite3.1-dense:2b: A malicious virus disguised as a joke is rapidly infecting Windows PCs, including 95, 98, ME, NT, 2000, and XP versions.
Dubbed Bagle.AT, Bagle.BB, or Bagle.AU, the virus steals e-mail addresses from Microsoft Outlook and sends itself to new victims using its own mail software.
Upon infection, it disables security measures on targeted computers.
The attachment carries a smiley or emoticon, and the email body is empty.
Security firms, including F-Secure, Network Box, and Black Spider, have reported numerous instances of this virus, with F-Secure assigning it its second-highest threat level.
Users are advised to be cautious of suspicious emails with attachments and maintain up-to-date antivirus software for protection against emerging threats.
chatgpt-4o-latest: A new variant of the Bagle e-mail virus, disguised as a joke, is spreading rapidly.
It infects Windows computers by tricking users into opening an attachment labeled "joke" or "price."
Once activated, it harvests e-mail addresses from Microsoft Outlook and disables security measures, including firewalls on Windows XP.
Security firms have issued high-level warnings, with reports of millions of copies being blocked.
Users are advised to be cautious of unexpected e-mails and update their antivirus software to stay protected.
